I am an avid reader of books on military history and this book had been on my wish list for a while. When I finally got my hands on it, it certainly did not disappoint.Intelligence (in the military sense and otherwise) or the lack of it has determined the course of wars and the fate of many lives for centuries. Espionage has been the glamorous arm of intelligence gathering, but cryptography has been the backbone on which nations have conducted their military operations and the fundamental building block of the digital world in which nations, corporations and individuals operate today.Cryptology has always been a battle between those who encode (cryptographers) and those who try to break the code (cryptoanalysts).This books traces the evolution of cryptography from the times of Mary of Scot (who was executed as her communication was intercepted and deciphered, proving that she was plotting to assassinate the English Queen), through substitution ciphers in the 19th and 20th centuries and how they were finally broken in the Arab world to modern times and the impact of Enigma on the outcome of WWII and finally the current use of RSA encryption and cutting edge quantum cryptography.I would recommend this book to only those genuinely interested in this topic as it requires a certain amount of concentration and effort to understand how the various encryptions work and how ingenious the logic to break those codes is. Without that effort, the beauty of the code and its break is lost on the reader.Recommended to those genuinely interested in cryptography and military history.

This is a very good book, one I've enjoyed very much. I knew Simon Singh from Fermat's Enigma: The Epic Quest to Solve the World's Greatest Mathematical Problem and The Simpsons and Their Mathematical Secrets, both of them books I liked. Thus with these precedents, it seemed a sure choice. It was.It is a little of the history of cryptography, as well as some anecdotes around it. Middle age in Britain and Scotland, World War (I and II), security in the Internet or quantum computers are some of the topics in which we trace the development of cryptography. The eternal battle between codemakers and codebreakers.I had almost no knowledge about this, only something about RSA and a bit of Enigma and Turing, so I learned a lot here. Besides I took notes while reading the book to further research on certain topics like Linear B or quantum computers. Amazing topics they are.I recommend it to anyone interested in cryptography, mathematics or just history. It's really a fantastic read you greatly enjoy.Also Simon Singh ends the book with a list of 10 challenges to solve. 10 cyphertexts you can decrypt if you have time and desire.

Since I suck at math, I was a little intimidated by this book when I bought it almost ten years ago. I finally decided to pick it up and read it, only to discover a wonderfully approachable discussion of cryptography. The mathematically inclined will enjoy the book just as much as those of us who aren't so equipped. And for the latter, the math is presented in a way that even I was able to understand it. Cryptography can be a confusing topic, but Singh strung it together as one mystery after another. The book is packed with stories of actual uses which keep it engaging, and I quickly wanted more of the technical discussions just so that I could find out HOW one encryption system after another was created and then broken. There's also a great deal of actual history, that isn't accurately portrayed by modern media.While Singh doesn't go into the details involved with how block and stream ciphers are currently used in modern data encryption, and doesn't discuss the various algorithms such as BLOWFISH, TWOFISH, AES, etc., overall he provides a wonderful overview on the core techniques used in encryption. After all, a symmetric cipher is a symmetric cypher, whatever the algorithm used, of which there are legion.

An excellent book on a fascinating subject. Simon Singh traces the evolution of cryptography and its perpetual battle with cryptanalysis right from ancient history to the end of the 20th Century in a very readable, entertaining style. He describes both the making and breaking of different codes over history, and details the algorithms in a very accessible manner. Honestly, you don't require any mathematical skills to appreciate any of this, but I guess it does take a certain kind of person to enjoy it so thoroughly. My only beef with it was that it has not been updated since 1999, so the "modern" chapters sound painfully out of touch ("Internet commerce is still in its infancy..."), and it would have been nice to read about developments made in the last 15 years. But given the quality of what's on here, that's a minor quibble. Besides, it ends with a wonderful description of quantum computing theory, which more or less justifies my "science is drugs" tag, so all is forgiven.However, the coolest part of the book has to be the Cipher Challenge at the end- a set of 10 enciphered texts for the reader to solve. I solved the first two pretty easily, and I'm working on the third one. They're supposed to grow in difficulty, so maybe that's as far as I make it!

In a word, "fascinating..."I was given this book as a gift from my aunt, to whom it was recommended from a mutual friend as an accessible and interesting history of ciphers and code breakers, it was both!Singh does a great job distilling a long history of the ongoing struggle between those who wish to keep communications secret and the minds that figure out how to unveil the secret communiques. The book is interesting to a layman such as myself, precisely because it moves through the history by focusing on secrecy and code breaking technological advances through indicative vignettes, ranging from Mary Queen of Scots to the Zimmerman letter of WWI and beyond. While I was not personally invested in the epilogue, Singh does provide a workbook of sorts to allow readers to attempt to decrypt (solve) example ciphers to apply lessons provided in the text; which is a cool idea, especially if I had the time/inclination.It has been a great aside from my normal self-selected texts, and certainly piqued my interest in some of the more secret service oriented maneuvers of WWII and the years that followed in Europe, so all in all a real winner!

I loved this book. It is incredible how clever some of these British cryptanalysts were. Without ever laying hands on an actual German enigma (though having a Polish reconstruction), they were able to crack it - mainly by exploiting not implementation weaknesses of the machine, but execution mistakes on the part of the German operators. Other tidbits from history were also quite amusing, as the Mary Queen of Scots section, and the brief overview of Arab contributions to cryptanalysis.I would say this is a good book for history buffs and geeks. It gives good insight into exactly how communications get cracked, and the various tricks used to con the enemy into spilling the beans. It also demonstrates many popular ciphers of old. I thought it was quite interesting how the Enigma machine was essentially a multi-stage, electromechanically-implemented version of the classic pen-and-paper two-stage Vignere cipher.I did not pay close attention to the section on quantum cryptography at the end, since the mathematics and concepts are somewhat over my head, and to the best of my knowledge, actual quantum cryptography/decipherment has not yet been experimentally demonstrated.

The Code Book: The Science of Secrecy from Ancient Egypt to Quantum Cryptography. An absorbing study of the history of cryptography and of the cryptanalysts that attempt to break them. It covers the story of the famous ENIGMA machine of WWII. The one disappointing aspect of the book came in the final chapter A Quantum Leap Into the Future, when in discussing the current strides in quantum computing, I realized that I was reading a new printing, the 22nd, of a book published in 1999. The current state of quantum computing is now as historical as the rest of the book.652.8 The Code Book: The Science of Secrecy from Ancient Egypt to Quantum Cryptography - A sweeping history of encryption, tracing its evolution and revealing the dramatic effects codes have had on wars, nations, and individual lives. From Mary, Queen of Scots, trapped by her own code, to the Navajo Code Talkers who helped the Allies win World War II, to the incredible (and incredibly simple) logistical breakthrough that made Internet commerce secure, the story of the most powerful intellectual weapon ever known: secrecy

This was a fascinating book about the history of codes, from the simple substitution code I use to solve the cryptogram in the newspaper every morning to hypothetical quantum computers (or are they hypothtical? Only the NSA knows for sure!). I was impressed that Singh described the math and science -- even the quantum physics -- in a way I could understand. Having said that, I found his writing style to be a bit too grad student paper-y for me. And as a debate coach, I found his analysis of the privacy debate (individual privacy needs vs. the government's need to prosecute criminals) to be VASTLY oversimplified. Still, I highly recommend this to anyone interested in puzzles, espionage, or both.

A review from someone who is not a mathematician, physicist, computer analyst nor an engineer. In fact, some of this material was visually familiar from the most agonizing and boring Cub scout field trip of my den-mom career, when we visited the National Cryptological Museum in MD. I learned from this event to always preview where you take the kids, It sounded so interesting on the website--I found this to be an enjoyable read, partly engaging historical background on various spy methods of hiding and encoding messages and then the book includes detailed tables of examples which were clear enough for me to follow. I opted out of the very last chapter on the future of quantum computers and cryptology. That was getting overwhelming to my Math phobias!

A fascinating romp through the history of codes and ciphers from simple ciphers, through Enigma into RSA cryptography and looking forward at quantum computers and their potentially perfectly secure environments, this is another great book from Simon Singh, who's yet to write a book I haven't enjoyed. He's outstanding at taking often difficult, technical subjects and presenting them in such a way that you can take as much from it as you like. If you know a fair amount about the subject, he speaks to you, but if you're a novice, the language is not too technical and daunting.The Code Book is a great read if secrecy, privacy, history, science and maths, or any combination thereof, interest you in the least.

I was completely hooked for the first 2/3rds of the book. For some reason, though, once I hit the chapter about Egyptian hieroglyphics and the following chapters about the present day science of cryptography, the book lost steam for me. Not Singh's fault, just a matter of personal preference. The early history of cryptography up until the World War 2 era and the story of the Enigma was all very fascinating. The story of the Beale cipher was awesome. Learning about the importance of the Allies cracking the Enigma was very illuminating. I had no previous awareness of the crucial importance of that feat. And the story of Ian Fleming's involvement around this time was awesome (he created James Bond)! I definitely recommend it.

Think of this as more like 3.5 stars. I was absolutely enthralled by most of this book. Singh's command of both the history and mathematics inherent in cryptography is stellar; I immediately began mentally planning some interdisciplinary units of learning. What keeps this from four stars is the final chapter and a half or so, and it isn't really Singh's fault. Modern cryptography is brutally dense and, of course, heavily reliant on computers. I simply couldn't keep reading without falling asleep on the T. Nevertheless, a truly interesting read for the most part and one I will definitely have to reference when teaching in particular about the history of warfare, as it's nice to know that defining moments hang as much on a series of letters as they do on a hail of bullets.

The Code Book gives a very comprehensive and detailed overview of the history of cryptography. One of it's greatest strengths is that it doesn't expect any prior knowledge of the reader, such as an advanced understanding of Mathematics or Computer Science. You could say it falls in the category of "Popular Science" books, but that doesn't detract in the slightest from it's comprehensiveness and usefulness.I used it as a textbook in the Cryptography 101 course I taught, and the students loved it! It also comes with software to try out a lot of the concepts talked about in the book. The Code Book CD-ROM, as it's called, is a bit outdated in terms of the user experience, and it sadly doesn't work on 64-bit systems, but apart from that, it's a great help.

A highly readable popular work on encryption, from the earliest substitution ciphers up through the Enigma machines of WWII, modern public-key encryption, and the possibility of quantum computation. Singh's book is really a textbook piece of popular science writing. Pick a topic that is (1) highly technical, but also (2) romantic and exciting. (3) Identify an organizing scheme (here: the arms race between code-makers and code-breakers) that you can return to periodically and use that principle to lay out the (4) history *and* (5) provide a pedagogical introduction to the concepts. The author hits all highlights and unless you're already an expert you're very likely to learn something. This is of course not the first or necessarily the best book on cryptography, but it's a fun intro.

A very informative book about an interesting topic. Singh is a great writer, and I have thoroughly enjoyed a couple of his books now. He does an amazing job covering the history of a single topic, and I would definitely recommend his books to anybody with even the slightest interest in the topic he is covering. This book in particular is fascinating. It shows the progression of cryptography and cryptanalysis throughout history, illustrating the constant fight between code makers and code breakers. Many times we have thought codes finally reached the point of being unbreakable, yet this always fails to be the case. Overall, this is a great read, especially for anyone with an interest in puzzles.

A superb work on the history and logic of cryptography, I should say. From the baffling hieroglyphics to the cryptic enigma, Simon Singh was able to cover the important parts that defined the art of writing and deciphering the secret messages that people are sending over from one place to another. Most interesting for me is how the art of replacing letter gradually shifted to producing encrypted one-way mathematical functions, a complicated process that has been useful in our everyday life ever since RSA publicized its findings. This is a good read for those who are not only interested with sending and receiving encrypted messages but also for those who want to create one for themselves and their companions.

He starts out slow, with plenty of seemingly superfluous classifications but if you bear with him through the first few bits, he takes off on a delectable journey through the ages. A very refreshing take on the pivotal role that the security of communication has had on our history, which ends with a meaty and balanced discussion of the precariously balanced state of secure communication in the digital age. There were points when he moves painstakingly slowly, especially when he is explaining how a code works or something similar, and it isn't technically watertight in the quantum cryptography section, but he manages to distill the outsider's perspective and layman's understanding into an engrossing and well-packaged whole. Definitely, someone I would like to read again.

You don't have to go to the nerdiest school in America, like I did (CMU. Sorry MIT you can't have the title. Your school has girls), to enjoy a book that is about the history of cryptography. No, really. Simon Sing weaves each of these items into an engaging narrative to introduce the concept. At times you'll forget that you're essentially reading a history mathematics. By the time he gets to the specifics of how the Allies broke the Nazi Enigma machine or the formula behind RSA encryption Sing has already gradually bumped up your IQ to allow you to understand it. Yes, you will understand it. You'll feel smarter for having understood it.

This was a engaging read. Even though I wouldn't say the title is completely inaccurate, it is a bit misleading. This edition of The Code Book is more of a synopsis of code history and code breakthrough both on the code making side and the code breaking side.The genius of some of those code makers and breakers is just astonishing. In addition to the great historical overview, it also discusses some of the security and ethical questions that we must face in this digital world.If you have an interest in code I would definitely recommend it, but if you have never been interested in code, this book probably would not excite you too much.

To anyone interested n the art of cryptology, this is the book for you. It is simply written so that any novice can understand why coding messages is so important and why breaking codes is the same. Singh basically writes a chronological history of codes and code breaking as it occurred over the centuries. There are some excellent individual stories along with stories of countries using codes. Writing how each code became more complex and how each code breaker came up with ways to break the codes is fascinating, especially the way that Singh writes. If you are interested in this topic, this book is one that you won't be able to put down.

Makes cryptography seem accessible to the reader new to the world of cryptography. I really enjoyed the intricate weaving of historical events and cryptography with a seamless weaving of the mathematical concepts to explain how those versions of cryptography work.The biggest drawback of this book is that it was written in the late 1990's, which is evident when discussing cryptography in the world today. It would be interesting if that section of the book would be updated to analyze the impact that 9/11 and the Patriot Act has had on cryptography.Overall, I would recommend this book. It definitely makes you want to encrypt everything you send over the internet, but in a good way.

Simon Singh does a really great job in both explaining the concept of a cipher and/or attack on a it, as well as putting them in a useful context throughout history. Personally I was more interested in the latter, as I was quite familiar with most of the presented ciphers already. To learn about their historical context was both interesting as well as insightful. To be honest, I wasn't aware of the fact, that cryptography is that old, especially that it was used that much throughout ancient history and that the life of so many persons was depending on it.Definitely a must-read for anyone interested in cryptography and/or cryptanalysis.

The book starts out and builds very well in the middle. It gives a good summary of the history of code-making and code-breaking. Some of the stories are really intriguing, the stories around WWII and the wars before that are a wonderful read.The book though begins to lose it's charm the moment it enters the post RSA phase of cryptography (post-1970). Explanation of RSA itself is too long and un-necessary (may be for those who know what it is), but the talk around quantum computing is absolutely useless. The book should have ended with RSA.Overall good fun read, could have saved some time not reading the end.

The truth is that I absolutely hate history books and I find history very boring. So, when one friend recommented me this book, I was afraid that I won't like it.Well, in fact, the book is surprisingly amazing! I love everything related with cryptography, so it was absolutely delectable for me to learn, step by step, all the evolution from the ancient years til nowadays!Thumbs up for Simon Singh for keeping all my interest through almost 600 pages! I would definetely recomment it, and I am going to read his first book too, I really hope it is as good!(I just felt it was a pitty that the cryptography competition is over by now, otherwise I would definetely go for it!)

Loved this book. Fascinating glimpse into history as well as a being a readable primer on how to create and crack ciphers. Gives clear illustrations and makes the maths clear without dumbing it down. I especially enjoyed the sections on Babbage, the Enigma machine and the introduction to RSA and public key encryption. My only criticism is that the last chapter on quantum computing was a bit too speculative and theoretical... But it is a very minor criticism. Happy to recommend this book to anyone with even a passing interest in the science of secrecy. P.S. Just noticed... This is my first five star review. :-)

This is one of the best non-fiction books I've read.Of course, the subject is inherently interesting. But Singh stays away from what could presumably be some very interesting stories, and instead goes through how a variety of ciphers were invented and and exactly how they work.This could be a very dense and confusing book, but he keeps it readable without being condescending (which many popular books like this would do).By the time you finish this book, you'll understand RSA/PGP encryption, the Enigma machine, the dechiperment of Linear B, and quantum cryptography. And you'll be able to explain exactly how they work.

My dad had a tall bookcase stuffed full of books. This would have been cool, but they were all technical manuals and nonfiction books about computing, science, and math. I would spend a lot of time standing in front of these books as he worked on his computer next to me. I'd try to find something new to read that I might actually find compelling or interesting. Every single time, I'd walk away disappointed and go back to re-reading my beloved SFF YA. One day, he recommended this to me.It was absolutely phenomenal. Highly readable and engaging, informative, and fun. A wonderful memory and a wonderful book. Would re-read.

Got this from the library.Very entertaining and good read, up until the last chapter, where the author passes from RSA and PGP into more complex encryption, where I completely lost interest and skipped to the appendices.I really enjoyed the interview snippets and the historical information, as well as the biographical information on the person he's speaking about. It really adds character and dimension to the person, instead of just a name and accomplishments. I took extensive notes and have some jumping off points now.I'm a little disappointed that he does not mention numbers stations.Would recommend to new to the subject readers.

I thought this book was fascinating. A book about cryptography can very quickly turn dry and boring, even for the nerdiest of us. However, the author impressively keeps things interesting, often describing different types of codes by giving examples of their use in history in a page-turning way. Even stories where I knew the end result - like the breaking of the Enigma during WWII - had me staying up far later than I should have so I could finish just one more chapter.Cryptography is one of my favorite subjects in computer science so I am probably biased, but I found this book to be well worth my time.

Singh has a good way of breaking down theory and concepts for the lay person, and making it feel like an adventure. This is a great primer on cryptography and it's history, told in a very engaging way. This, in my opinion, is what good non-fiction is about - drawing you in as much as any novel, with interesting stories that are made even more amazing because they're true! It made me want to read more about a vast array of subjects that Sing touches upon, in fact I picked up a book on Linear B today! (Though it isn't a "code" per se, Singh touches on lost languages since unraveling a lost language employs a lot of the same strategies that code breakers use.) Do it! Just read it already!

An excellent overview of cryptography's influence on the world, and its inner workings. Singh travels swiftly but satisfyingly from the pre-crypto days of 'invisible' clay tablets, through the spy games that lost Mary Queen of Scots her head, into the war-altering mind-games of WW1 & 2, all the way up to current 'civil rights vs organised crime' dilemmas, and even off into the nearish-future of quantum cryptography. Interleaved amongst the history are dalliances with everything from 'boys own' challenges to examples of translating forgotten tongues, all embellished by the characters and happy accidents that have driven this 'arms race' on. 4+

I thought "The Code Book" was a very informative and interesting book. Although it was interesting, I did have a bit of trouble getting through the quantum leap part of the book. It wasn't as interesting, to me, as the other parts of the book, such as where they wrote messages on people's heads, or executed Queen Mary. Overall, I thought the book was great, but there were just a few parts that were too complicated for me to understand without having to read it over many times, and I don't enjoy having to re-read things to understand them. I would suggest reading this to anyone who has any interest in codes, it is an interesting read.

Skillfully written and engaging history of the 2000+ year old struggle between the people who try to make messages secret and the people who try to decipher them. Singh is brilliant at creating detailed examples phrased for the general reader to demystify the math behind most modern cryptography, as well as finding historical examples of cryptography's often crucial role in world events. The only reason this book gets four stars instead of five is that it outdated... the last 10 years have seen exponential growth in the use and role of crypto, and this deserves a new revision to keep up.

Can't say I followed everything in this book but I comprehended enough to enjoy it immensely. The secret codes used in early Western History (substitution and frequency codes) are easy to understand i.e. Mary Queen of Scots secret messages were fairly simple and it's a wonder she wasn't beheaded earlier. The Enigma machine and quantum cryptography made me dizzy. The author includes "fun exercises" in the back of his book. I skipped them. My brain is too out of shape. I mainly read this for the history of cryptology and I finished this book very satisfied.

I am definitely not a maths geek and it's a tribute to Singh that I could follow the theory of cryptography enough to be excited about the process itself as well as the history of its role in politics, war and internet security. Fascinating at every stage. I found myself wanting to know what has happened in the 15 years since the book was published. His last chapter forecasts the current debates sparked by revelations of mass government snooping on mobile phone and internet communications. A great read somewhat to my surprise.

Another reviewer put it best in calling this geek porn, which is exactly what this is. The history, the math, the computer science, the linguistics, the politics: all of it was addictive. Some parts of the chapters did become more technical in how a process works but those I was able to follow along with due to my background in computer science; if you couldn't or didn't want to, you could just skim it and catch the gist. The last two chapters suffer the most due to the age of this novel but it's easy enough to imagine continuing his predictions forward, but an update would be fantastic.

I was all set to give this book five stars, but, well, we’ll get there. The book started out very strongly. I loved the detail. The histories are well-told and rich with contextual detail, and they paint a colourful and compelling picture of the evolving nature of cryptography and cryptanalysis from ancient times till the first and second world wars. There are moments now and again where the level drops right down Spot The Dog Does Codebreaking and the level of simplicity is actually a bit excruciating, and then it will suddenly leap up to Get Your Cryptography PhD Here, but these are forgivable given that at times the book attempts to explain the inner workings of complex machines undertaking even more complex tasks to total amateurs.But then something weird happens. Maybe the book needed to be finished or the topic got dry or the author lost interest. I don’t know. For about the last 25%, where the book turns to the digital age, the polish is lost. Sometimes it feels like whole paragraphs are repeating the same thing in different words, or that the ideas are disjointed, and that the meticulous care of the first three quarters just wasn’t present for the finish. Another major, but unsurprising issue, is that this book is now nearly twenty years old and the datedness is particularly obvious in the later sections on the internet, email, and online commerce. All that could be done here would be a revised second edition, but then, in another twenty year, we would be in the same position, so I would most strongly recommend this book for what it has to say about the origins of cryptography and cryptanalysis, and not so much for the current state of the art (which has presumably moved on radically in the past two decades).Overall, then, this is a fascinating read from start to finish. I learned a huge amount from it, touching on everything from quantum computing (which I now know at least something about, versus previously when I knew nothing) and photons to Euclid, prime numbers and factoring, to the work of various security agencies, and even some of the vagaries of the academic fields in question. It’s engaging, informative, mostly well-written, and the appendices at the back are an excellent addition, including as they do a series of ten increasingly difficult codes for the reader to break. In short, I strongly recommend it.

Singh eloquently retells salient moments in the history of code-breaking from the emergence of steganography, with examples including the Babington Plot and Demarcus' betrayal of Persia, to the transition from the mono- to poly-alphabetic cipher, namely the Vigenere Square due to the ramifications of Arabian-devised frequency analysis - a core example of the basis of cryptography . These key moments, and others including the cracking of Scherbius' one-time pad cipher, the Enigma machine, by the ingenuity of Rejewski and the Bletchley group, are intertwined with comprehensive but not exhaustive mathematical analysis that partially illuminate the underlying discoveries of modern mathematicians and linguists in this field. In short, Singh's book provides a competent indulgence into some of the subjectively important events in the history of code-breaking with a diverse range of examples stretching from the use of Navajos language in the Pacific by the Americans in WW2 to the deductions of Kober, Ventris, and Chadwick unveiling the origins of Cretan lost language famously named Linear B as well as the advent of Zimmerman's 'pretty good privacy' encryption to the general populous. In addition, topics such as quantum computing as well as a more poignant discussion into the divide between privacy and security are transiently addressed. In summary, like Singh previous work ('Fermat's last theorem'), this is an approachable yet roundabout glance into cryptography providing an adequate synopsis or introduction into a detailed, a naturally secretive, field.

Political assassination plots, romantic liaisons, military secrets, and buried treasure are just a few of the themes wrapped up in the history of cryptography.This book makes an dry and highly technical subject extremely accessible. First, by telling these stories from history -- ranging from the assassination plot by Mary, Queen of Scots against Queen Elizabeth of England in 1586 up through the political martyrdom of Phil Zimmerman for the invention of PGP encryption, which brought computerized encryption to the masses and ushered in the era of secure online commerce. And second, by providing plainly-written step-by-step descriptions of the functioning of each cipher and the technique that can be used to break it. It should be noted I have a professional background in software cryptography, but I still think these descriptions would be understandable to a lay audience.For example, a monoalphabetic substitution cipher (what I call "secret decoder ring cryptography") was the world's gold standard for encryption for thousands of years -- until Arab mathematicians invented frequency analysis in the 9th century AD, almost completely nullifying the value of that cipher.Thus began the arms race between cryptographers (aka codemakers) and cryptanalysts (aka codebreakers), a multi-eon game of cat and mouse between thousands of the world's mathematical and linguistic geniuses. This war is fought almost completely behind closed doors because of the massive military value of secure communications, so most of these individuals didn't get recognition for their work until after their death.One of the most tragic cases is Alan Turing, who broke the Enigma cipher during World War II, and in the process invented the modern computer ("Turing machine"). Despite having almost single-handedly defeated the Nazis and creating the technology that would usher in the Information age for mankind, his work was considered military secrets and known only to a few. He was outed as a homosexual in his middle years, resulting in criminal prosecution and chemically castrated by the government. He committed suicide a few years later.The book also takes a chapter to dive into a related topic: deciphering ancient written languages. While not cryptography, similar sleuthing techniques can be applied to try to read written texts in languages that have been lost to humanity's collective knowledge. The book details the deciphering of Egyptian hieroglyphs (made somewhat trivial by the discovery of the Rosetta Stone, the ultimate crib), and Linear B (a script used in the kingdom of Minos, the place where the labyrinth/Minotaur legend originates). Linear A remains undeciphered and continues to enthrall the minds of linguists and codebreakers to this day.The book was written in 2000 and concludes by talking about the battles between civil libertarians (who wished to make encryption freely available for all) and governments (who wish to control encryption as a weapon of war). This is instructive in and of itself -- just in the twelve short years since that time, this issue has been completely resolved. The civil libertarians won, and as a result we have a thriving online economy made possible by asymmetric key cryptography.
