His writing is very clear and conscience making it a very simple and fluid read, but I still feel as though I become a better reader and writer due to the discrepancy in our literary abilities. Overall, I just love reading his books. My favorite part was definitely the section about internet cryptography, diffie-hellman and RSA public key cryptography. These were all concepts I was familiar with, but this text brought a lot of clarity to it in terms of how it's implemented, how it works, and I really enjoyed reading about the history behind how these algorithms were created and the people who created them. In particular, I also loved that he shed light on Ellis at GCHQ. I had also known for quite a while that quantum computers could brake our cryptography but never understood why until reading this book. I loved every bit of it.That being said, everything from how Egyptian hieroglyphics were being deciphered, to the Rosetta Stone, the various cyphers (monoalphabetic, enigma, vigenere) all have fascinating stories and histories behind them. Small things like knowing that the decipherment of the enigma machine started in Poland, and Alan Turing based his grand ideas on the work of previous cryptoanalysts. Or the fact the Beal ciphers had never been deciphered and gold may still be lying around. Perhaps that the young professor (whose name escapes me) was so excited by his decipherment of Egyptian text he fainted. It's also hard to believe that in the 1970s, there were messengers flying around the world delivering keys because there was no other way to exchange keys. All of this is extremely interesting, and it's amazing to see how far we've come and see the path we took to get there.Thank you for putting this together Simon!

I was actually looking at all the images, trying to decipher the codes and understand the convoluted designs. If a book can get me to do that, it gets 5 stars, hands down. Also, the author is an incredible storyteller.
(I’ve only read the first 2 chapters) It’s a really good book, combining history and cryptography. I plan to finish it soon!

I really enjoyed the majority of this book, as it traced the development of code-making and code-breaking. Some of the material was familiar to me, as I recently read The Girl Who Smashed Codes, but I feel this book did a much better job of explaining the process of code deciphering. Starting with the simplest shift cyphers, it walks the reader through monoalphabetic cyphers, the Vigenere square, and more, showing weaknesses and ways to attack these codes, such as frequency analysis. I was especially impressed with Singh's clarity in revealing the processes of the Enigma, Germany's encryption machine from WWII, and his detailed explanations of how this complex code was cracked. Another chapter that amazed me was "The Language Barrier," which discussed the decoding of Linear B script from Minoan Crete. The Code Book demanded very concentrated brain power from me, especially when it got into the nitty-gritty of computer encryption and the solution to the key-distribution problem. For the first time in my life I encountered the concept of modular arithmetic, which I think I understand the basics of now, though I'll probably have lost the details by tomorrow morning. (Alas, if only I could hold onto everything I read!!). Anyway, I only skimmed the last chapter of this 1999 publication, which covers Singh's musings about the now-past future of cryptology. One really cool feature of this book which I did not avail myself of: after the appendixes are a series of increasingly difficult ciphers. Really motivated readers can take what they have learned from the book and put it into practice. Honestly, my brain is too tired to even try!4 stars, though I wish Singh would write another chapter on the advances of 2000-2018! Still, everything but the final chapter is completely relevant to today, and presented in an exciting and comprehensible way, even for non-math and computer people.

In addition to providing a brief history of cryptography since its known inception, this book provides some excellent how to s on code breaking (and making). As a not-so-technical geek, I found the explanations clear and easy to follow, particularly on the current RSA method of encryption. A far more techy-geek friend tried to explain the concept but didn't make it clear; subsequent Wikipedia study left me still in the dark. But Singh came through, finally enabling me to grasp the concept.The book also contained a number of anecdotal tidbits I look forward to following up on. The mathematician who told the poet that 'a man born every minute' should be changed to the more precise '1 1/16 of a man born every minute' literally made me laugh out loud. Poland's triumph over the German Enigma machine after Britain and France gave up made me clap my hands. The Navajo contribution to American WWII security was awesome.There were some things left hanging. I was left curious as to the of Polish cryptographers after German invaded, not to mention curiosity over how they kept the enemy from realizing Enigma was cracked. I learned that the head of Britain's WWII team was punished even more by the government he'd served. And the author's reference to the Kama Sutra as a book teaching women how to work on practical skills left me wondering if there were two books of the same name (there aren't).Overall, however, I found the book a fascinating and easy read (though it would have taken me more time had I actually taken the author up on his frequent code breaking challenges). Very insightful and educational.In fact, clarify just how smooth and interesting it was read, I'm suggesting it my year old, spy (and , but not book) obsessed son.

Anything with a bit of Math in it was going to interest me anyways :) That said, the narrative was overall good. The chapter on Enigma was a really tough one personally. I feel perhaps a few more illustrations could've helped. I may re-read that chapter just to understand a bit more.

Really good history overall with a few flaws, none of them a deal-breaker.One was perhaps inevitable: the way the mathematical and computational content is presented. While Singh gets credit for avoiding the dismal trend in science writing for a general audience towards glibness, he sort of finds an unhappy medium. This content is in places described in sufficient detail to say something concrete, yet leave something essential out. Since I read this book as a prelude to more a technical exposition of cryptography, I eventually decided to focus mainly on the historical content, as well as skipping most of the discussion on Linear B and the final chapter's discussion of quantum cryptography. (That stuff is not historical as such and—barring classified breakthroughs—too far away for me to be greatly concerned with at the moment; in any case I'd rather approach it with a stronger grasp of quantum mechanics and quantum computing.)Surprisingly, he also repeats the myth that ARPANET was devised to keep vital military communication alive in the event of nuclear attack.But overall this was well worth the read and amazingly brisk. Unless my focus is stronger than usual, Singh has a real knack for clear writing.

i have always been fascinated by codes and encryption, so i really enjoyed this book about the history of codes. after all the history of codes is history: wars, spying, intrigue, politics... the book starts with the earliest known codes from Greek and Egyptian times and works through all the major conflicts in history. starting around WW1, the story of codes merges with the history of computing, as the first machines were invented and then enhanced. Singh does a great job highlighting the incredibly critical role that codes (Alan Turing and his machines, the Navajo code talkers of the Pacific, Enigma, etc.) played in how WW2 turned out. the most interesting part for me was a straight language description of the modern encryption standards like DES and RSA. i finally understand these after years of using them. the book was published in 2000, so it finishes with an early look at the growth of the internet and the first wave of massive information gathering by the NSA. lots of great info...would like to see an updated version one day.

An excellent read. I never realised how far back encryption went and how interesting it’s history (present and future) can be. Mary Queen of Scots undoing was weak encryption. World War II’s allied victory is attributed to the information received through the breaking of the Enigma code. Treasure apparently buried in the USA with the location encrypted and published in the Beale Papers (yet to be decrypted). Today we are all indebted to cryptographers who developed DES and RSA encryption without which shopping online would not be possible.The Code book also goes through the process of how Egyptian Hieroglyphics (both in meaning and phonetics) were deciphered, and the ancient language of the Mycenaean called Linear A and B, (although Linear A has yet to be deciphered).Overall this is a very well written book that allows you to understand the intricacies of encryption and decryption and at the same time keep things interesting.

After reading Cryptonomicon (one and a half year ago), I decided I wanted to know a bit more about cryptography and ordered this book. It took a while for me to start it (one and a half years), but it was definitely worth it. Singh takes the reader through the history of cryptography, pretty much from start to near-future and does it in a way anybody can understand. His writing style is very 'chatty', informal, and he often tells fun and engaging little (true) anecdotes and stories involving crytography to illustrate his points. And talking about illustrations, this book is chock full of them! And they are often well chosen and very helpful.Many times, I wished he would go a bit deeper into the technical details, but I understand this wasn't his aim when he wrote this book. I suppose I'll have to do some further reading for that. For what it is though, I feel this book couldn't do its job better.

This book was essentially a primer on cipher-breaking, stepping through the most primitive monoalphabetic ciphers and advancing through the decipherment of Enigma in WWII and the birth of modern cryptography. This story is well appointed with historical narrative, but this starts to fade fast in the modern era. While the drama of cryptography and cryptanalysis was literally a matter of life and death in the time of Mary Queen of Scots and through to WWII, western courtrooms strip the drama down like a collapsed soufflé. Furthermore, I ran into a challenge against my expectations from when I bought the book: I was thinking this was a recent publication from Singh. In truth, it's actually one of his first books, and the sources he cites when discussing the importance of modern crypto are already ten years dated. That doesn't make them any less valid, but in the Information Age, a decade is a very long time to overlook.

The title pretty much says it all: Secrecy in communications from Ancient civilizations to the current age RSA ciphers and a peek into the future of cryptography. The book is very well written in terms of maintaining the balance between the technical details of various ciphers and interesting tales from history where the respective cryptography techniques played a crucial role. At places I felt that the author could have made the mathematical details less elaborate. But I suppose its done deliberately so that the book can be accessible to wider range of readers. The chapter on RSA topic is a good read. Starting from the roots of the search of pre-agreed key less method and how that lea to Public key cryptography.I really liked the part at the end too, about Quantum physics, quantum computing and quantum cryptography. It definitely aroused my curiosity regarding Wave-particle duality. I am going to look for books, not totally technical physics textbooks, o these topics.

It is a great book about the history and development of ciphers and the battle to attack different kinds of cipher. The stories in the book suggest how important ciphers are in shaping the modern world as well as in daily life. The ending chapter of the book also raises the wariness of people about privacy and how to protect privacy in the modern Information Age. The only downside of this book is the fact that it was written more than 10 years from now, which mean that many technology that is described as "modern" in the book might have been obsolete. Based on the information given in this book (as well as other sources online) and my little knowledge of Java programming, I was able to write programs that mimic and even enhance the Enigma cipher, do automatic Vigenere, Affine and Ceasar encryption and frequency analysis. I am also working on RSA and Diffie-Hellman public key transferring algorithm on Java based on the description in the book. Thanks so much Mr. Singh!

I found this book exceptionally interesting and extremely well written. It mixes up the details of code making and breaking with their historical details in a really readable manner. I found all the technical details very easy to follow (and unlike other 'pop-science/maths' authors, it isn't over simplified to the point of being incomprehensible) and in sufficient detail that I can understand the formal aspects at work. The historical side was really interesting and it was all wrapped up in a very followable package. Whilst the internet side already seems like it is starting to need updating (one example involved a 1MHz processor...) it had some very prescient points and the fundamentals, to my knowledge, are unchanged. The section discussing how much access governments should have to our private communication, given the recent revelations about how much access they do have, was particularly interesting. Highly recommend for anyone marginally interested in cryptography!

Come to find out that I'm a tough grader... no 5-star ratings, as yet... I like when non-fiction books feed me detail a little beyond what I actually want... this book did that... fluid writing style that builds tension and then pays off... for the most part, it did... one that ties together improbable elements like Mary Queen of Scots and the Enigma Cipher... yup... but I was ready to put it down... the great ones you want to go on forever...His discussion of the future of cryptography (this book written in 1999) presages the Snowden affair and the continuing battle between NSA surveillance and individual privacy rights... he does his very best to make quantum computing understandable and interesting... I loved the intrigue surrounding Mary QOS.... but the best bits were on Enigma/Ultra and on the deciphering of Egyptian hieroglyphics, IMO... this is a very good read and not too long... highly recommended!

I've been chasing this book for ages (I think it was recommended in the further reading section of Cryptonomicon?), and ended up having to get it through an inter-library loan. I'm really glad I did - it's lucid, readable, charming, and surprisingly funny. It has some great stories, and some great examples for you to play along with. Most importantly though, it describes some truly funky mathematical ideas in a way that a non-mathematician can actually follow, while still highlighting the breakthrough required to come up with them in the first place. I really enjoyed this, and I plan to track down my own copy to keep and lend out to other people. Even if it is a little old.(The last chapter or two, on the future of cryptography, are simultaneously super dated and weirdly prescient in a post-Snowden landscape. )

What a fantastic, invigorating read. Cryptographic techniques explained in the context of major ND minor historical makes for one unexpectedly wild read. Upon finishing the book, one can expect to fully appreciate the genius that goes into both code-breaking and code-making. I am a software engineer, and I have done little work(wait, none) in the area of cryptography. This book exceeded my expectations and served as a delightful introduction to the topic. The beauty of this book is that it can be appreciated by anyone except the most knowledgeable of experts. Singh is capable of taking a florist, and enabling them to converse with and enlighten peers on both future cryptographic methods and those of the years gone by. I will now move on to the book 'Applied Cryptography: Protocols, Algorithms and Source Code in C' by Bruce Schneier, as it provides practical teachings for implementing many of the modern algorithms discussed in this book..

By carefully combining the technical details of the development of cryptography with a rich and fascinating description of the relevant historical context in which each major breakthrough occurred, Singh has managed a remarkable feat: he has created a piece of technical non-fiction that is a real page-turner.In each chapter, he explores another aspect of the great battle between codemakers and codebreakers, creating suspense and tension, and simultaneously explaining how the process works, from interception to deciphering, with emphasis on the social and personal costs.For puzzle fans, math nerds, or history buffs, this book is like crack. You'll zoom through it, only to find yourself wishing for more when you're done. But, the author's clever storytelling ability makes it accessible and compelling enough to get anyone hooked.

excellent book for the geeky inquiring mind. Goes from the methods used to decipher Egyptian hieroglyphs, to other key historical stories involving broken ciphers and the military applications and work done on codes and code breaking by brilliant minds in the field of cryptology. Moves on to the internet era with good explanations of encryption methods for the masses and how the extraordinary minds of the geeky minded civil libertarians who believe in privacy for the average person (the masses - lol) worked so hard to invent these things for us. Ends with an overview of quantum mechanics and quantum physics theories, 'ideas', critical overview points... and goes on to discuss what some possible ramifications will be when we figure out how to build a quantum computer. Yes I am a geek...

The main reason Chassy lent this book to me is for the chapter explaining asynchronous or public key cryptography, which makes secure communication over the Internet feasible. I had to read that chapter twice, but I am happy to say that I understand it now.However, the rest of the book is pretty amazing too. The Beale Cipher is a fantastic story (and which I believe is a hoax, although you never know), and cracking the German Enigma machine is an important and often overlooked part of W.W. II history. On top of that, you get Linear B--a fascinating tale of how a dead language was resurrected.It is interesting to note the early deaths of many of the wunderkinds and polymaths whose achievements comprise this book. One is bound to get the impression that a great mind is doomed to die young, but I wonder if perhaps they all chain-smoked.

Simon Singh traces the history of cryptography (creating secret codes) and cipher-breaking (code breaking) explaining each step by exploring more and more complex codes. Singh begins each chapter explaining how each new secret code was discovered finishing with how it was cracked. I experienced the same emotion with each chapter. First, amazed about how clever and creative the code creators were. Each new code seemed unbreakable but by the end of each chapter I was even more surprised by the genius of the code breakers and how they found weaknesses in the codes to exploit. This book was a good "Math Geek" book being both technical and complicated at times. Little was held back in the areas of mathematics which I appreciated. I would recommend this book to any who finds this topic interesting.

Most of the book is very good. Reminded me of Timothy Ferris' "Coming of Age in the Milky Way" (which is amazing)—both good historical narrative along with the nuts and bolts of the science. All the material up through WW2 kept me super engaged. Slight drawback is his over-over-over explanation of technical details. "Yes, I already know how the Enigma machine enciphers, because you explained it ten pages ago. And ten pages before that. And ten pages before that. And I still remember all three times you've already explained it." But other than that, really engaging. But after WW2 it starts to go downhill. RSA and public-key encryption sections are okay, PGP is mediocre, and the chapter on the future of cryptography is downright bad. So first 70% of the book is really good; after that it's your call whether to keep going.

One of the most intriguing and interesting books I've read in a very long time. This was actually a required textbooks for a friend's college course, and I borrowed it after he was done with the class. I literally read it in five days. Me, having studied linguistics, absolutely loved everything this had to offer. From the story of Mary Queen of Scots to cracking the German Enigma cipher to encryption in the digital age, there was simply so much to learn that I couldn't put it down.This book was written in 1999, back when the digital age was picking up enormous speed. I can only imagine what changes in codes and encryption have happened since then, and hope that Singh would come out with an updated version of this book sometime in the future.Must read for puzzle and language and math lovers.

Really enjoyed reading this. It provided a good history of of cryptography and cryptanalysis. My favorite part was the discussion of the work to crack the enigma code. Imagine that the ability to read or not read Nazi communiques literally meant the difference between life and death to members of your family, community and nation. Imagine that your activities in this intellectual pursuit of decryption made you a target of Nazi Germany. It's not just a puzzle you are solving, but life and death is in the balance. On another front, imagine that you had broken the enigma code and were responsible for saving countless lives, only to be imprisoned for a homosexual act with no one knowing your role in the war? In the end this book, brought a very human element to what might seem such a cerebral activity.

An amazing overview of cryptography. Like the title suggests, the author takes us through history to show how cryptography has changed and evolved. It is such an interesting story.I felt the last few chapters had the most bang for the buck. Considering the PRISM project has been unveiled by Edward Snowden and run by the NSA, I couldn't help but compare what some of the early pioneers of cryptography, like Phil Zimmerman, warned when information was speeding around the internet without being encrypted.I definitely recommend this book if you want generally learn more about cryptography. The explanations are at times a bit dry and go on and on, but for the most part it is essential to understand them at a basic level (like symmetric key encryption, RSA, PGP, etc) if one wishes to discuss the implications of them.

I loved it. For me, a few things are better than to work your brain, feel intelligent, see things with a clear mind. SO that is why I liked it that much. But it's not for everybody.. difficult book, it sucked your attention from the outside world, if you read it properly of course. I've started three times before I've finally been able to finished it. Because I wanted to cherish the knowledge, use my brain and think through while reading. Finally I've found the time, on my vacation; during the day, on the beach :) evenings, on the balcony with the wind.. Not an ideal holiday for most of the people, I know :) to learn something on your free time; deal with math, solve cryptic texts or so. But, it was perfect for me. My only regret is, that I wish I've come across this book at the year 1999 :)

this book combines computer science as well as historical account, both are my favorite topics, which make this book highly enjoyable. I already familiar with a couple of computer science story (ie:the once powerful enigma machine, the tragic story of alan turing, etc) as well as some historical account of WW2 (ie: karl donitz, the highly successfull nazi admiral that eventually became hitler's successor), but finding the relationship between those two was quite eye opener. turns out that part of donitz's success was due to his men's discipline not to use regular predictable pattern when using enigma machine, the only hole available for british cryptanalyst to crack the code.another nice feature inside this book is that, the author spent lots of pages describing the personality of each actor, something that you can't find on cryptography course book. 5 stars.

3.5 stars. Funny how things in life collide- In the middle of reading this, I saw the movie The Imitation Game, which is all about- you guessed it, code breaking! I'm happy I read some non-fiction material about Alan Turing before seeing the movie so I could tell what was just made up to make the movie more dramatic. Really fascinating work, and I can't believe it stayed classified for so long. I loved reading about the history of code breakers from ancient Egypt to WWII to more recent computer encryption. What I wasn't so into were the extensive examples and explanations of the minute details. I'll admit I skimmed some of the detailed math, which is why this isn't a 4 star book for me. Wish I had read something about code breaking way back when so I could have passed encoded notes to my friends in class.

This book presents a great introduction to encryption, including the history of trying to keep information secret, the process used to break some of the more famous ciphers and codes, and even examples of how decryptions works. The book provided good details but didn’t get too technical in most places. The author provides an extensive list of materials for further reading and research so it’s easy to find more information on any topics of interest. While it is a little bit of a digression, I enjoyed the sections of translating ancient languages like Egyptian hieroglyphs and Linear B the best. I’ll admit, I didn’t find the final sections of the book on current web security and digital encryption methods as interesting as some of the older history. Overall, an enjoyable and informative read.

Oh my gosh this book is the ultimate thriller for nerds! Even though the 2 last chapters are a tiny bit outdated, since the main focus is the history and evolvement in cryptography you should have no problem with the accuracy of all the information in here. It's particularly interesting to see how cryptography involves such a wide range of fields from mathematics to archeology and linguistics, which means no matter what type of nerd you are you would definitely find some topic you love! Especially if you took a course in abstract algebra and studied factorization of polynomials, you would find lotsssss of cool stuff in here! No worries if you don't have a strong math background though, Simon Singh did explain everything really thoroughly in my opinion, so definitely check the book out if you're in need of an exciting non-fiction :>

I almost feel I need to downgrade many of the books I've given 5 stars because this one was at another level. Great book!I recommend this to anyone interested in math, history computer science or all of the above. There's even a chapter that deals extensively with archaeology and linguistics. The research is incredible. However, do not shy away for fear of math. Almost all the math is simply straightforward, and its most of it is not even necessary that you really understand. The only part with slightly more advanced math is very well explained, and even if you don't understand it, the general concept will suffice to continue on in the book.I recommend the print version because of the graphics and the cipher challenge at the end.

I was bought this book for Christmas a couple of years ago and didn't expect it to be very interesting, but I was very wrong. I have a background in mathematics and eventually read it because of something that came up at work, but I'm really glad I did. It's very well written, describing the progression of cryptography through the centuries. Various important events are described in enough detail to give the reader an understanding, but without going into a lot of technical detail (although many references are given for those who are interested). I would recommend this to anyone with a casual interest in the subject. People with a scientific or mathematical background would probably get a lot out of this book, but anyone can follow the descriptions of the various cyphers.

This book was written in 1999, so the information is a little dated. There is no mention of AES, lattices, or elliptic curves, but the information the book does cover is substantial. The author describes the cryptanalytic process for each cipher discussed in detail, even going pretty deep into quantum cryptography, for which he explain's Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, superposition, and photon spins.There is a full section on linguistics and the deciphering of hieroglyphics and Linear B, as well as overviews of the lives of dozens of cryptographers and cryptanalysts like Alan Turing, Martin Hellman, and Whitfield Diffie.

Made me realize the importance and depth of cryptography. As a science student with interests in the field of arts such as history, this book really made me turn the pages wanting for more. Although quite long, definitely a good read. After finishing this book, want to try some more on much more advanced science fields, such as bioinformatics, blockchains, and artificial intelligence.Also made me realize how and what real geniuses are really like. Being able to speak multiple languages fluently at a young age, publishing an astonishing paper in their undergrad years, makes me realize what a small person I still am.

Both readable and educational at the same time. I wish there were more books like this on other topics. Want to know something about history of cryptography? Then tis it the book for you; it covers the wole history beginning with ancient Egypt and Greece, lists the impact of cryptology and cryptoanalysis on the world wars, and it is rounded off by breef summary of possible future in quantum mechanics. Have you known how Alan Turing died and what was his role in Enigma break through? Beacause I have not and I was very surprised by that..

The Code Book is an excellent overview of the history of cryptography, presented here as an eternal neck-and-neck race between codemakers and codebreakers. Singh's writing is engaging and I found this book just as readable as his Fermat's Enigma. I particularly enjoyed the stories of the Navajo code talkers and the deciphering of the Egyptian hieroglyphics using characteristics of the Akkadian language. Well done.

This felt more like a thriller than a non-fiction. It's quite captivating, wonderfully showing the race between cryptographers and cryptanalysts. The part on the Enigma and how it got broken was simply mind-blowing, my personal favorite. Simon Singh explains the technical concepts of cryptography in a very clear way, even for the non-technical reader, and captures the awesomeness of this field of science throughout history. The book is concluded with a treat of cipher challenges for the reader to indulge in. A great read !

Probably the best generalists' introduction to cryptography and its history published in recent times. Singh cleanly explains the history and concepts, expertly showing the evolution of codes and ciphers, and the methods used to break them; and how they changed the course of history at various important points.The chapter on Quantum Cryptography might take several readers to grasp the concepts, but that's not Singh's fault. Blame the universe for acting so screwy at subatomic levels. Singh does a fine a job as any author could explaining the subject.

This book was amazingly approachable and actually fun to read. It explains cryptography through a chronological series of important events. In each event, the course of history was changed by a secret being unlocked or kept hidden by a new cryptographic idea. In addition to being entertaining, this format lends itself well to concepts becoming incrementally more complex as history plays out. The concepts build on each other very smoothly and were much easier to understand than I expected.I've always been curious about how security works. Now I know!I highly recommend this book.

"The Code Book" was a very interesting manual on cryptography. I especially like the book because it sequentially went through the development of modern cryptography and tied it together with historical events. The book dually taught cryptography and history; assuring that the cryptography aspect would stick because of the history behind it. The book really did cover everything from "The science of secrecy from ancient Egypt to quantum cryptography". "The Code Book" is essentially a manual and a tremendous one at that. Simon Singh did a fine job with this book.

Simon Singh's books seem to be quite enjoyable because he dives deep into the history of a field, crafting cinematic narratives out of what might otherwise simply be disjointed events in history. Most of the book was fairly simple (read: boring) for anyone who's taken a Crypto 101 course, but it was amusing nonetheless. Chapter 5 (The Language Barrier) talked about deciphering ancient lost languages (such as Linear B) briefly, and that was definitely my favourite chapter, along with Chapter 8 (about quantum cryptography). Overall, it's certainly a good book!

Great book. To bad I'm hopeless in math. What I found interesting is the history and importance of cryptology and how it could make our break successful campaigns. The future and importance of data security is now of equal importance in the mass market due to the proliferation of computers. We need to protect our security from crooks as well as overzealous governments. Governments need also to make sure crooks and terrorists are dealt with swiftly. Really wish my understanding of math was better to appreciate this great book more fully.

I enjoyed it a lot, and I keep wondering if I lost a lot of content by choosing this edition instead of the original one...I'd like to know more about Egyptian hieroglyphs (because they're in a different language), about Purple (because it was just mentioned - not explained), about the Navajos (why did they agree to collaborate?) and about RSA (because it's just frikkin GENIUS). I'd also like to rip open an Enigma machine... wonder if they sell those on eBay?

I've had an interest in cryptography most of my life so I was already aware or had at least heard of most of the topics/concepts written about in this book but I was still impressed with the way that Simon Singh presented the subjects. The book shows the human element of cryptography and places the abstract concepts in their historical context. My only disappointment is that the book is very much out of date in terms of modern computer cryptography but I suppose that cannot be helped.

Mr. Singh's book on cryptography and cryptology is a fascinating read, if you're already interested in that sort of thing. It's a little breezy in parts, and the chapter on quantum computing and cryptography gets a little dense (unless you've already got a good grounding in quantum physics, I suspect). Even so, it's a great book for stimulating thought about concepts like privacy and what we consider to be privileged communication, or how we would protect it.

Lots of fascinating stories from history about how different codes were broken from antiquity to modern times. Admittedly, I was less interested in the encryption methods for computers than the ones used during the world wars or the uncovering ancient texts. I skimmed some of the more technical aspects of the book, preferring to concentrate on the impact of breaking various codes and the people who were able to do so. Enjoyable read - 3.5 stars.

This is an excellent and thorough introduction to cryptography and newcomers to the field will hopefully be drawn into the world of codes, code-makers, and code-breakers. Even if you are not new to cryptography you will still gain something from it. I'm pretty well-read in this area but enjoyed the explorations of some topics I was rusty on, including the Vigenere cipher and the analysis of Linear B.

This book was truly amazing! I have always loved math and codes, the author broke everything down to simple enough terms for anyone to understand. It was quite amazing to read about so many people were unable to talk about their achievements in code breaking until decades later. If you have any interest in code making, breaking, or how forgotten written words are unlocked this is the best book I have read for it all.

The book holds your hand through the history and evolution of cryptography through the ages. I found the parts on modern cryptography a little hard to get through having studied it previously and there not being much history/drama to that part of the book. Still, it's only a small portion of the book and the rest more than makes up for any lack of excitement in those chapters. Fascinating read, highly recommended!

A very interesting and well-explained history of cryptography and crypto analysis. The explanations and examples made sense without seeming too dumbed-down. The last two chapters are the least interesting because they become a discussion of cryptography by computer. It makes sense to discuss this, but the time it took to explain the concepts felt like a drag. Also, many of the claims about the future of computing (written in1999) are a little dated.

"You have idea number 1, you get excited, and it flops. Then you have idea number 2, you get excited, and it flops. Then you have idea number 99, you get excited, and it flops. Only a fool would be excited by the 100th idea, but it might take 100 ideas before one really pays off. Unless you're foolish enough to be continually excited, you won't have the motivation, you won't have the energy to carry it through. God rewards fools"--- Martin Hellman

This great nonfiction book takes the reader through the history of secret writing, through early codes to the complicated ciphers of the modern age. With helpful charts and diagrams, as well as enciphered messages in the back for the reader to practice their newfound codebreaking knowledge. One of the best nonfiction books I have read, pretty much anyone could become interested in this topic just by reading this book. A definite 5/5, and a wonderful, informative, and interesting read.

A really interesting history of cryptography - lots of fascinating historical case studies, which I loved reading about - and, lots of good advocacy material in here for those working to enforce privacy rights nowadays, too. It was heavier on the practical aspects of breaking certain codes, and in some cases I skipped through these rather than following them step by step (though, if you're more inclined to follow the techniques through from start to finish - it would be a very good read!)

Extremely informative book, talking about the history of codemaking and codebreaking throughout the years.Provides entertaining accounts, including firsthand interview with some of the world's leading cryptographers.Includes easy to understand analogies and examples that explain cryptographic concepts.Appendices at the end provide great insight into further reading and some of the unsolved mysteries of cryptography.

One of the more interesting books I have read this year. Its fascinating to read regarding the war between code-makers (cryptographers ) and code-breakers ( cryptoanalysts ). How encryption enabled Germans to dominate the World War II and the importance of code breaking or crypt-analysis has been explained vividly by the author. The ending of the book is bit weak, else its a wonderful read overall

A really interesting read that did an excellent job of explaining how asymmetric keys and RSA encryption work. The tone of the book seemed to shift about halfway through when the topic switched from simple codes and ciphers (like the Caesar cipher and the German Enigma machines) to data encryption. It could use an update, though, as it was written at the turn of the century and we've come no closer to quantum computers but have seen a rise in cryptocurrency like BitCoin.

Starts with the foundations and progresses towards more complex forms of cryptography, and with each step Singh provides clear examples and explanations that you yourself can work through. The immense intellectual force required to crack the Enigma machine during WW2 left me in awe, as did the simple and beautiful solution to the 'Key Distribution' problem. I would love to see a revised edition to go into everyone's favourite topic today: cryptocurrencies.

Very good. Quite detailed on the Enigma cipher, this bit though slows you a bit, or so I felt. Really good and very much simple reading. After this book picks up pace once again.Overall a very good read. Covers the history and the major techniques in crytpography well enough for the lay man and the avid fan.

Today I down-graded this from three stars to two stars. I remembered being bored all the way through the parts I read, and wanting it to be so much better than it was because it covered such a fascinating subject: the decoding of Linear B. I have been deluding myself thinking that I was missing his genius. He's a second rate brain.

A very good read from Simon Singh, giving an overview history of ciphers and codes and code-breaking. The author also explains the various cipher and code systems at, for my liking, just the right level of detail. 3 stars from me is perhaps a bit mean but I didn't feel it was quite engrossing enough to merit 4. Still very much a recommended book.

Engrossing, accessible, and very educational from beginning to end. My only criticism would be that, despite a repeated theme throughout the book about how we become very confident that a cipher is secure, only to discover it's not quite as secure as we thought... the book concludes, without a lick of irony, discussing how quantum cryptography is the final word in crypto. :|

A detailed history of cryptography, the various algorithms for encrypting data and techniques for decrypting messages. Considering the complexity, the book is very easy to read and hard to put down. There are a few puzzles at the back of the book for you to solve - some of them will require much more computing power than your desktop computer offers.

I loved all of it, except for the PGP chapter as it didn't really seem to fit into the rest of the book. I'm starting to feel that I don't hate maths after all, I rather feel like I've been taught to hate it, or that I taught myself to think I'm rubbish at it, but I'm starting to gain some interest in it after all this time. Fantastic book, highly recommend!

Do you know how important the breaking of the Enigma was to winning the World War 2? Do you know about the Swede who broke the even harder cryptography machine?This book takes you through the history and highlights the importance cryptography and codebreaking have had in how things have turned out. It's a fascinating read that will give you a new perspective in how to view the world.

Great general overview of the history of cryptography. Coming from a computer engineer background with some exposure to cryptography, the book was a little repetitive and too long in its explanations. Some stories I've heard of but the book provides more insights such as its historical significance and what the people were thinking.

Well written book about the history of cryptography. I was familiar with a lot of the information, however the author did a good job of adding specificity and context to the different techniques. Also the author explained complexities of this field in relatable and approachable manor. Enjoyable read.

I would have liked a more technical book but he wouldn't have been the one to tell it. This book tells a fascinating history full of intrigue reviewing the relatively recently declassified works of the code breakers of WW2. The appendices filled in where the text stopped. If only need researched the quantum chapter better he might've avoided a few inaccuracies.

A broad-ranging and excellently written account of a number of interesting topics directly or tangentially related to cryptography, written for the layman but without watering down technical detail unnecessarily (and the appendices contain a bit more of this in certain areas). Very helpful as a backgrounder / primer for people working on distributed cryptosystems.

Some of this stuff was over my head, but it was a fascinating book. I thought the explanation of computer encryption could have been better, but I loved the part about the Enigma. Gave it to my son to read next.

1 star because the historical part of the book is basically a ripoff from David Kahn's The Codebreakers. As many people know, this is my main interest in crypto and when I picked up the book, I almost threw it up in disgust.

One cannot fail to appreciate the ingenuity of modern cryptography after reading this. The author presents an unbiased view about its ramifications on the modern day society. Most importantly, the book contains umpteen anecdotes making it a definite page-turner.

Great stories, and comprehensive descriptions of security technology. From Queen Elizabeth, to Alan Turring, to Quantum theory. Fun to read and informative.The best description of private key encryption that I have ever seen.

Compelling narration. The author has complemented facts and history in an excellent way. Recommended for anyone interested in cryptography and to those trying to understand the importance of mathematics.

There were lots of interesting bits in this book, although some parts were a little dry for me. Unsurprisingly, my favorite part was the information provided on WWI and WWII. I need to finish watching The Bletchley Circle...

Much better than I expected. I thought it might be a rehash of Kahn's "The Codebreakers", but instead, it brought "The Codebreakers" up to date. Good explanations of how codes and ciphers are invented, implemented, and broken.

This book has rocketed me into my profession. It quite gently describes the evolution of codification (how to attribute meaning to predetermined symbols) how it works and what are the tendencies ahead.

If you are interested in cryptography this book is a must read. History of codes and coding is explained in a straightforward way in a book that comes across as being meticulously researched. Highly recommended.

Great book on cryptography. It details the history, application, and breakdown of how cryptography developed and evolved. The intricacies about how each crack worked was explained in great detail without being tedious.

The book is well balanced. It covers history, mathematics, a bit of philosophy and politics, and explains the evolution of cryptography in light of society as it was at various times. The interplay between the development of cryptography and the real world is shown rather well

A interesting book which explains some of the important codes and breaks over the last few hundred years. It did feel somewhat flat at times. also, giving it was published in 1999, it miss much of the geo-political changes that have happened since; not it's fault, but makes it somewhat dated.

Fantastic story of the development of codes from ancient times, through modern code breaking (including the WW2 Enigma machine) and with side journeys into ancient scripts. Easy to follow, we written and enthralling throughout.

The author gives a nice overview of encryption over time, being sure to satisfy those who are interested in the actual mechanics with out overwhelming the uninitiated. The stories of the people involved were intriguing, and I learned a lot about how encryption works on the internet.

Every line of every page of "The Code Book" is packed with rich detailed historical information of the world of cryptography and secret-codes of the last millennium. I enjoyed every minute I spent reading this book, albeit, once I started it was difficult to put down.

A little outdated now since it was written in 1999, and I know there have been more advances in coding since then. However, this provided great insight in to behind the scenes mathematics throughout history. Good book to skim and gain information into an interesting an untold topic.

One of the most interesting book on the subject. i recomend it to anyone interested in Cryptography and its history. well written and good english, makes it easy to read, the only negative aspect to it, is seeming bit dated

This book is more about the historical background of ciphers than about the cipher systems themselves, which disappointed me greatly. If you're a cryptography fan, this book is for you. If you're serious about cryptography, don't even bother.

An imaginative and fantastic presentation of the history of cryptography. Even though the book is rather outdated as of today, it contains interesting pieces of information that explain everything in a simple manner for a non-expert.

I really liked this book on the historical evolution of cryptography. My only quibble (though no fault of the author) is that the book was written in 1999 and encryption and identity theft/protection have come a long way since then that the narrative feels incomplete. Otherwise, a great read.

Honestly, one of the best non-fiction book I've read. Although, it's not completely a computer science book, I'll put it right up with Charles petzold's 'Code' in terms of how well-explained a lot of concepts are.

This book completely absorbed me and guided me through the history of code-makers and code-breakers. I recommend to all those people that want to know more about techniques to protect their privacy.This is the Information Age !

This is the first book which ever got me interested in encryption. It is simple enough for the layperson to understand, but detailed enough to give you a working knowledge on every major type of coded communication. A great starting point for anyone with a budding interest in cryptography.

This is the only book I read on the subject even though I worked on some of SSL protocol related thing, This book put the whole crypoto+encrytion stuff such a beautiful way that anybody could catch it up.

Excellent book. Highly accessible and readable considering how dense the topic could have been. It benefits from the fact that at its heart cryptology is about secrets and spying which lends itself well to real life dramatic stories. Highly recommended.

An excellent overview of the history of keeping secrets through cryptography. It is not math intensive, but there are some technical parts. It brings in historical elements, including the Code Talkers and the Turing Machine in World War II.

Very readable despite touching on some tough concepts (such as quantum cryptography). The book centers around the narrative of cryptanalysts versus cryptographers from prehistoric to modern times with a significant amount of content around the second world war and the Enigma cryptographic devices.

A very interesting read going back to the origins of cryptography and how methods have evolved over the centuries. I must admit that my eyes glazed over at times so I flipped through a few sections. Regardless, the author did well to explain and illustrate concepts.

ways to encrypt your private letters, keeping them safe from colleagues or nosy siblings;• how a weak code had a very serious impact on Mary, Queen of Scots; and• why your government will do everything it can to keep you from using the next state-of the-art encryption method.
yeah - geek porn is right
This book is awwweeeesooommmeee!! No complaints. Go read it.
excellent book! very engaging and full of history, math, computer science. I will be obsessed with cryptology for at least several more weeks.
The history and technology of secret communications. Great stories, including Mary, Queen of Scots and Enigma cracked by Alan Turing and Bletchley Park.
Incredibly well researched book. The first chapter, with the historical account of Mary, Queen of Scotland's attempted to send secret messages was my favorite part!
This book is an incredible introduction to cryptography. The writing is incredibly clear and engaging. Singh is charming. It's just great.
Very interesting book about encryption and its historic development. Highly recommendable if you are into maths/computer science/history.
The clearest, most enjoyable and entertaining book I have read on cryptography. It is such a fascinating area, but most authors make it so boring.
Good microhistory; this book is enjoyable but not engulfing or one you'd cite for years. I would recommend, but I would recommend Mary Roach's work more highly.
A wonderful book that helped me understand cryptography and why we should trust electronic banking! Just don't ask me to try and explain these concepts to anyone else. Read the book.
This was a fascinating book. I highly recommend it if you wonder at all about how we can send credit card information across the internet without it being stolen.
A fascinating book that touches on math, history, and technology as it uncovers the evolution of cryptography.
The narrative arcs keep this interesting, and describe cryptography in a captivating way, revealing how codes have changed the course of history.
A great high level overview of cryptography through the years, with some great examples and plenty of resources to follow-up on. I have a lot of highlights and margin notes with this one.
Great book for anyone interested in codes and code breaking.Well written, not just a boring academic look into this subject.
easy to understand yet extremely interesting, even for persons who got absolutely no brain for mathematics.
A history of cryptography in the world, up until 10 years ago. Fantastic introduction, made me want to learn more. Also loved the tangents into linguistics.
I'm really looking forward to the cryptography module next year so that I can actually learn the maths.
Great history and discussion of cryptography, although I wonder how outdated the last chapter is, having been written in 1999.
Absolutely engrossing. Highly recommended.
Fell in love with cryptography...... This book has changed my perspective of a boring subject to a subject worth spending life for.
I'm fascinated by puzzles, codes, and cryptography. This is by far the best book I've read on the subject — very thorough and well-researched but also entertaining.
Awesome book. I learned a lot. Maybe I'll write a review.
"deciphering is, in my opinion, one of the most fascinating of arts"
dragged a bit in the computer parts since I know how RSA works already, but the historical parts were interesting
This was the most interesting book I have ever read!!
I loved this book, a really engaging and understandable look into the history of cryptography.
Great book - clear, well-written and with the right amount of detail to understand the key concepts. Would be great if it were updated at some point to reflect the advances of the last 17 years.
Very informative and interesting read on cryptography.
This is a crazy readable book. Highly reccomended for anyone who likes math, science, history (especially military history), and mystery.
Gilles story was depicted at the end of the book. :)
